title: Pyke voice lines are utterly disappointing
body: They sound great but they missed out so many interactions that would've been so cool to have. Tahm, Naut even warwick. Seems rushed tbh

replies.body: Yeah, I was a little disappointed with his interactions.

tbh I don't think that someone is pleased with the interactions at all..

I mean for a bit, it seemed like new VO's kept getting bigger and bigger, but now they seem to be shrinking. Camille, Xayah and Rakan all had a pretty large amount of interactions, but Kai'Sa and now Pyke seem to be extremely lacking (Pyke even more so than Kai'Sa).

The leads added new restrictions to script lengths.  While i disagree with the exact number they took, we absolutely needed to limit the audio files size/number creep.  

The writers (like matt) are attempting to find the best places they can give maximum value within those new restrictions.   Unfortunately, it’s a subjective call and will never be right for everyone.  This is in no way meant to discourage or dispell your feedback— quite the opposite — keep it coming.  

Rito absolutely listens, it just takes us longer than you think to shift.  (I.e a champ’s design takes 6+ months.)

I get all this, and understand it. 
But when you see a champion like Pyke, who's got a basic story that is almost verbatim Nautilus' story (albeit with their own unique flairs), and they're both prevalent in the same region in the world, how did someone on the design team decided to NOT have a line for Nautilus? Why did someone say "Hey, let's make a line for Ashe," and completely forego a champion who it would make more sense for Pyke to have a common bond with?

So I'm gonna be totally honest.  (buckle up)

When Pyke was entering pre-production, narrative was also looking at Nautilus's lore.  He along with Fizz and a few other champs were still outliers from our recon / current lore.  

And there **was** concern Pyke was too close to Nautilus. But internally, our leads felt that Pyke hit the "revenant" thematic better than Nautilus.  Then the plan was to change Nautilus's lore significantly-- prior to Pyke's release.  

--And actually they were going to change Nautilus to something I pitched to solve the problem.   (Namely: Nautilus was a person seeking redemption within the cult of Nagakabouros.  He was a man that had agreed to have his soul placed in a sacred golem. An extremely difficult and lonely duty working as a sentinel for as long as he could keep... going.)    Internally teams loved it.

**BUT** that pitch was then taken to players with a rather larger survey and... the players hated it.  They wanted Nautilus to stay a revenant.  

Yeah. Uh.. oh..

 By now Pyke was well into production (and VO) and it was uncertain how / who was going to fix Nautilus.  (And I was on another project)   

  My assumption was that Matt did not know what Nautilus was going to be (or that Naut was going to stay the same) when he wrote the lines for Pyke-- so he avoided the character-- because he didn't have anything to write towards.

I really like the insight you just gave. It makes sense. I always wondered why riot asked about how players felt about Nautilus lore out of nowhere, but now  it makes sense seeing as how Pyke would have a similar story.

Thank you for that, I've seen stuff from FauxShizzle, and he didn't particularly explain _why_ there weren't lines for Nautilus, just that he didn't do them/cut them, so having that backstory that his lore was potentially undergoing changes is understandable and explains so much.

That being said, it's not particularly refreshing to hear that you guys are so utterly willing to gut the lore of existing champions just because you've created a new champion who fits the theme better. That kind of translates to a lack of respect for the old champions for us players, who actually play those champions and come to love them. That's the main reason why people hated the pitch of such a dramatic change of lore - you have a story, already written for a champion, that you want to cannibalize and replace with something else entirely because you want a new champion to have that lore. Not cool at all. If you wanted the revenant theme for Pyke, you needed to completely push him in a different direction. The whole undead ripper thing is a good way to do it, but you need to commit to the theme so we can be told a unique tale using a similar backstory (like you have it seems).

That leads to my next point though - Pyke doesn't come across as dead. At all. He comes across as a male Illaoi. Both have the glowy eyes, and both have spectral/spirit elements to them. Nothing really distinguishes Pyke visually as being dead, because we're reminded so much of how Illaoi interacts with her god. Pyke's skin tone is a very natural, living skin tone, which doesn't sell us undeath, and his recall shows him combatting a leviathan, which again doesn't sell us undeath. Overall, he _feels_ like a mystical pirate more than an undead pirate, and that to me is a pretty big flaw in his visual design if you were aiming to sell us the LOL pirate version of Freddy Kreuger. A good start would be to pull the warm colors out of his brown skin tone, and use a gray/blue underlay for his skin instead, so we're instantly aware that he's got an unnatural pallor.

Actually, I as far as I know this was the first time this was attempted.   

But in defense of the process it wasn't done  Willy-nilly.  **You have to change stuff to try and make things better.**  And... thus you will sometimes fail.  

Times change. Character's that do not change are dead.  They fall away forgotten.   i.e. Batman has been: funny, Goth, dark, nippled, lego, and gloomily envious of superman.   My dad loved the Adam West version and hated all others.  I love the dark knight.  There is no right answer.  Only versions that are successful or not.

>Times change. Character's that do not change are dead. They fall away forgotten. i.e. Batman has been: funny, Goth, dark, nippled, lego, and gloomily envious of superman. My dad loved the Adam West version and hated all others. I love the dark knight. There is no right answer. Only versions that are successful or not.

Batman has been around since 1939. It's been disingenuous to point to a character that's been around for almost a century and use that as an example as to why a character that's been around for half a decade should change completely.
In 1939 it took weeks to travel around the world.  Now you can do it in a day.  We live in a time when things change faster every day.
Achilles and Odysseus did not have to be changed for their stories to remain for thousands of years.

> But in defense of the process it wasn't done Willy-nilly. You have to change stuff to try and make things better. And... thus you will sometimes fail. 

I disagree. I already talked with Bioluminescence and Scathlocke about it, but I guess I'll do it one more time.

You can elaborate on what exist, you can add new stories, new perspectives, new facets to a character. But changing what's already done should be a very last resort, should be an exception. You should accept what's there as a base, and do the best you can on those foundations, with an isolated retcon once in a while, again, as a last resort.

I'm not opposed to ANY change, but it's a matter of scale. As it stands, you are far too willing to retcon everything and start from scratch. It makes me lose all confidence in the Lore. Why should I invest time and feelings in the story if anything can change every couple years?

And the comparison with comic books is very disingenuous. Each version of Batman was its own self-contained story, and comics have dozens of different time-lines / parallel universes to host the many versions. LoL does not. So I agree there isn't a *right* answer, but there should be ONE answer, because Runeterra is still only ONE universe with ONE timeline. Having too many versions makes me feel like it's no universe at all.
Are you excluding the times the lore of existing champions was gutted for the new story of a new/reworked champ? Because that’s a good sized list...

Hey, just wanted to say I'm always a fan of your work. It's interesting to hear more about the behind-the-curtain process of VO (personally my favourite part of champion updates).

If I may ask something in regards to this:

> we absolutely needed to limit the audio files size/number creep.

Is there anything more you can tell us about the interaction-quote-selection-process, and if possible (I understand this is a big ask and I don't want to come off as entitled) if Vlad players can look forward to anything during the Aatrox update?

Thanx.  (Also I'm a total sucker for compliments)  
 
  The process is not limited to interactions, so for instance, Aatrox has frankly less "Move" lines than I am comfortable with-- but he has more interactions with top laners than any champion previously made. (Aatrox will be introducing a new type/category of line for league, which I think people will like.)  
  
In general, we have "general line minimums" for a script. So a champ has at least: 25 Move lines (triggered when clicking to move greater than 900 units), 15 LongMove lines (triggered when leaving base, mid tower is up, and clicking greater than 900 units), 25 Attack lines etc...   

Then based on the position a champion plays you may have other minimums too.  (So a character designed as a split pusher might have lines for destroying towers, while a support might have lines for placing wards.) 

Now once you've filled in those core minimums you might have specific gameplay needs.  (Kled yelling Charge!, Sion yelling Cowards!" etc...)

Then finally, you have "X"number of lines left.   This is where you use lines for "misc other stuff"  e.g. lore, jokes, alleviating player pain  (i.e. Zoe groaning "Darn it" when she misses a long Q) This is where the writer prioritizes and makes judgement calls.  (For instance, maybe you have a targonian character that has some lines for Taric... the lines are super funny.. but your character is a midlaner.  Is it better to have lines for someone they might actually lane against?  Hmmm  -there isn't a right answer.)

 I remember writing a line or two for Vlad... but I honestly don't remember if it got culled. (As Vlad is mostly a mid-laner and Aatrox is mainly a top-laner.)   I will say Aatrox really, really, **really** hates Zoe. (He as a very good reason too hate her-- but also I like to make fun of my, and the designer's previous champs).

His personality is very different than Rhaast or Varus. They are only just getting "free."    I can't reveal much, but internally and in player labs-- people love him.

Well that's immensely disappointing.

There were a lot of interactions, but ultimately it didn't feel right for the character to have a lot of VO lines toward other characters. People to him are either on his list or going to be on his list. As an unhinged murderer, he's not close to a lot of people, or even aware of their reputations. They are just names to be added to and then crossed off his list. Many times, champ-specific VO lines don't fire as often as other lines that reinforce the in-game fantasy. 

Sorry I disappointed you on this front, I hope you'll still find some fun playing Pyke and reading more about his character.  Thank you for taking the time to respond, I really appreciate you :)

I know I would kill for Ekko to have dozen more interactions with other champions ( how the hell does he have only 5 minutes worth of VO?!). That's just my personal opinion. Hopefully, in the future, you will allow more champion interactions. It is undeniably my favorite part of a champion's VO being released.

Comically enough, a lot of people told me the opposite about Ekko (why is a bunch of his lore in champ interactions which never fire?). It's okay though, you can't please everyone. 5 minutes for Ekko was a lot when we were working on him. Consider that when we did Ekko, most champs had under 1 minute of VO (and some still do). TBH clear -- VO is something Riot is ALWAYS working on, fussing over, experimenting with, and trying to make better while doing out part to keep patch download times down. Every narrative writer's favorite part of the job is writing VO. Sometimes we went overboard and wrote more for more's sake. That also wasn't the best idea. We are in a place where we believe the VO and number of lines, type of line triggers MUST be right for the champ we are making. Some champs don't need to be chatterboxes or have a lot of pre-existing interactions with other characters since they're lone-wolf type characters. 

One thing I absolutely hear and love hearing, is how much players love the VO and the interactions. We want to satisfy the itch to have more interactions in other storytelling efforts. That doesn't mean we are going to ignore in-game stuff (btw), but it does mean we are going to choose who champions interact with carefully and why. Our processes are evolving constantly, and we strive to grow and get better and we DO listen to your feedback and take it to heart. 

Thanks for chiming in, everyone. The next couple of champions I'm working on do have more interactions (bc their characters really do call for it) and I'll write a few extra bc I know you guys like 'em. They won't ALL be taunts though.

TBH clear -- VO is something Riot is ALWAYS working on, fussing over, experimenting with, and trying to make better while doing out part to keep patch download times down. Every narrative writer's favorite part of the job is writing VO. Sometimes we went overboard and wrote more for more's sake. That also wasn't the best idea. We are in a place where we believe the VO and number of lines, type of line triggers MUST be right for the champ we are making. Some champs don't need to be chatterboxes or have a lot of pre-existing interactions with other characters since they're lone-wolf type characters. 
>

For the record, taunts are actually some of the least plausible character interaction triggers. Kled and Camille are perfect examples with their vast majority of kill triggers that have a lot more opportunity to go off, as we'll more than likely be killing opposing characters. It's a bit difficult in the middle of a game to plan to be close enough with enough time to do a taunt to a relevant champion. 

A game I played during it's brief life was DC's Infinite Crisis. It had proximity interactions between the heroes that triggered automatically without taunt or joke inputs, but they were limited to 1 run so you didn't get constantly trigger it whenever you got close. So for instance, If Harley Quinn was in lane and the enemy Joker walked up to her, she'd shout something like "Sorry puddin', I'm going to have to give you the hammer now!" and so forth. It was a great way to trigger interactions that would allow you to seamlessly play the game and hear fun banter without having to stop and input commands within a certain distance of someone.

I've found that with Riot, particularly in the last couple of years, reality rarely meets expectation.

It's why I never expect cool interactions between new champions, or kits/in-game visuals that I would have expected based off champion teasers.
